questions.question: Which statement creates a new function called discountPrice?
You need to match a time value such as 12:00:32. Which of the following regular expressions would work for your code?
questions.explanation:
**NOTE**: The first three are all partially correct and will match digits, but the **second option is the most correct** because it will **only** match **2 digit** time values (12:00:32). The first option would have worked if the repetitions range looked like `[0-9]{2}`, however because of the **comma** `[0-9]{2,}` it will select 2 **or more** digits (120:000:321). The third option will any range of time digits, single _and_ multiple (meaning `1:2:3` will also match).
**More resources:**
1. [Repeating characters](https://regexone.com/lesson/repeating_characters)
2. [Kleene operators](https://regexone.com/lesson/kleene_operators)

Why is it usually better to work with Objects instead of Arrays to store a collection of records?
questions.answer: Most operations involve looking up a record, and objects can do that better than arrays.
questions.explanation:
[Reference efficiency of lookups](https://stackoverflow.com/questions/17295056/array-vs-object-efficiency-in-javascript)
**Explanation:** Records in an object can be retrieved using their key which can be any given value (e.g. an employee ID, a city name, etc), whereas to retrieve a record from an array we need to know its index.
correctAnswer: Most operations involve looking up a record, and objects can do that better than arrays.
options: Objects are more efficient in terms of storage.
Adding a record to an object is significantly faster than pushing a record into an array.
Most operations involve looking up a record, and objects can do that better than arrays.
Working with objects makes the code more readable.

Why might you choose to make your code asynchronous?
questions.answer: to start tasks that might take some time without blocking subsequent tasks from executing immediately
questions.explanation: **EXPLANATION:** `"to ensure that tasks further down in your code are not initiated until earlier tasks have completed" you use the normal (synchronous) flow where each command is executed sequentially. Asynchronous code allows you to break this sequence: start a long running function (AJAX call to an external service) and continue running the rest of the code in parallel.`
correctAnswer: to start tasks that might take some time without blocking subsequent tasks from executing immediately
options: to start tasks that might take some time without blocking subsequent tasks from executing immediately
to ensure that tasks further down in your code are not initiated until earlier tasks have completed
to ensure that the call stack maintains a LIFO (Last in, First Out) structure

questions.question: What is the difference between the `map()` and the `forEach()` methods on the Array prototype?
questions.answer: The map() method returns a new array with a transformation applied on each item in the original array, whereas the `forEach()` method iterates through an array with no return value.
correctAnswer: The map() method returns a new array with a transformation applied on each item in the original array, whereas the `forEach()` method iterates through an array with no return value.
options: The `forEach()` method returns a single output value, whereas the `map()` method performs operation on each value in the array.
